Although the study highlighted ApoE4's resistance to phase separation and condensate formation, it also underscored its involvement in mitochondrial dysfunction within AMD pathology. The presence of arginines, as opposed to cysteines in ApoE2, altered protein properties significantly, suggesting a varying impact on RPE health and the development of AMD.
title: Mitochondria-dependent phase separation of disease-relevant proteins drives pathological features of age-related macular degeneration

finding: The study found that individuals heterozygous for the APOE4 allele (APOE3/4) experienced lower AIHH-induced changes in diaphragm motor-evoked potential (MEP) amplitudes compared to other APOE genotypes, with a statistical significance of p=0.048. This suggests that the APOE4 genotype was associated with a reduced capacity for neuroplastic response to AIHH.
title: APOE4, Age & Sex Regulate Respiratory Plasticity Elicited By Acute Intermittent Hypercapnic-Hypoxia

finding: Similar to the findings with rs429358, the presence of the APOE4 allele indicated a detrimental effect on AIHH-induced phrenic motor plasticity, with heterozygous individuals (APOE3/4) showing diminished diaphragm MEP amplitude changes. The combined analysis of both SNPs revealed critical insights into the role of the APOE genotype in respiratory motor plasticity.
title: APOE4, Age & Sex Regulate Respiratory Plasticity Elicited By Acute Intermittent Hypercapnic-Hypoxia

finding: The SNP rs121908028 was associated with familial hypercholesterolemia and linked to LDL receptor functionality. The provided text indicated that this SNP was part of a characterization of transcript variants related to cholesterol metabolism regulation and statin efficacy, in conjunction with the analysis of LDLR and its transcript variants.
title: A prostaglandin alpha F2 analog protects from statin-induced myopathic changes in primary human muscle cells

finding: The SNP rs121908029 was also identified as part of a network characterizing LDL-related functions that are altered by statins. The context highlighted its association with familial hypercholesterolemia, contributing to understanding individual responses to statin treatment.
title: A prostaglandin alpha F2 analog protects from statin-induced myopathic changes in primary human muscle cells

finding: The SNP rs28942083 was included in the analysis of LDL receptor variants linked to cholesterol metabolism. This SNP was specifically noted for its connection to familial hypercholesterolemia, providing insights into the genetic basis of statin efficacy and muscle health.
title: A prostaglandin alpha F2 analog protects from statin-induced myopathic changes in primary human muscle cells

finding: The SNP rs748944640 was similarly associated with LDL receptor variants and was implicated in cholesterol homeostasis and statin response. Its relevance was established in the context of the study, underscoring its role in familial hypercholesterolemia.
title: A prostaglandin alpha F2 analog protects from statin-induced myopathic changes in primary human muscle cells

finding: The variant rs2304256 was noted to regulate junction-skipping in TYK2, which is associated with rheumatoid arthritis, indicating a potential link to the disease.
title: Junction-skipping regulation in complex disease

finding: Similar to rs2304256, rs34725611 was found to regulate junction-skipping in TYK2. This observation supports the association of this variant with rheumatoid arthritis.
title: Junction-skipping regulation in complex disease

finding: While the specific nature of the association was not detailed, rs3760638 was identified among the significant ASCA-SNPs that correlated inversely in formative and primed-associated RNMs, suggesting an impact on pluripotency cell states.
title: Unsupervised Machine Learning Identifies Chromatin Accessibility Regulatory Networks that Define Cell State Transitions in Pluripotency

finding: The SNP rs429358 was associated with the homozygous ApoE4 gene variant. This variant resulted in the editing of the ApoE allele from T/T to C/C, changing the amino acid from Cys112 to Arg112. This alteration was confirmed via sequencing and was relevant for characterizing the impact of ApoE4 on intracellular transport and iron homeostasis at the blood-brain barrier in the context of Alzheimer's disease.
title: ApoE4 disrupts intracellular trafficking and iron homeostasis in an improved iPSC-based model of human brain endothelial cells

finding: The SNP rs7412 defined the genetic variant of base position C/C (Arg112) which was present in both the parental and subclone ApoE4 homozygous line. This genetic information was critical in understanding the effects of the ApoE4 allele on endothelial cell function related to Alzheimer's disease pathophysiology.
title: ApoE4 disrupts intracellular trafficking and iron homeostasis in an improved iPSC-based model of human brain endothelial cells

finding: The SNP rs429358 was identified as a significant site related to the APOE locus. A specific haplotype containing a C at rs429358, along with a C at the nearby SNP rs7412, was found to confer risk for late-onset Alzheimer's disease. This association indicated that knowledge about the genotype at rs429358 could substantially inform about a user's Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Attacks on genetic privacy via uploads to genealogical databases

finding: The SNP rs7412, in conjunction with rs429358, was also linked to the APOE-ε4 allele, which is known to increase the risk for Alzheimer's disease. The findings suggested that accurate genotype recovery at rs7412 could be achieved through the methodologies described, allowing for better understanding of genetic predispositions among individuals.
title: Attacks on genetic privacy via uploads to genealogical databases

finding: Rs10406644, mapped to the KCTD15/LSM14A gene, exhibited significant 1df interactions with short sleep duration (STST) and was part of the multi-ancestry analyses that identified three novel loci associated with increased BP levels.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide gene-sleep interactions identify novel loci for blood pressure

finding: The SNP rs1065853 was found to be the top ranked SNP associated with the immature red blood cell percentage trait. It maps to an intergenic region between APOE and APOC1, where both exhibited significantly decreased expression when analyzed (APOE log2 fold-change = -0.63, APOC1 log2 fold-change = -0.27). This highlights its regulatory involvement in lipid metabolism and related health conditions.
title: Discovery of target genes and pathways of blood trait loci using pooled CRISPR screens and single cell RNA sequencing

finding: ERCC1 rs11615 was studied in the context of colorectal cancer and has been associated with grade 1 neuropathy in patients treated with oxaliplatin. The mutant T allele showed a connection to this lesser degree of neuropathy.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: ERCC2 rs13181 was linked to treatment effectiveness in oxaliplatin therapy, indicating its relevance as a pharmacogenomic marker in colorectal cancer treatment.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: XRCC1 rs25487 was suggested to affect the efficiency of DNA repair, which may lead to increased efficacy of oxaliplatin, thus acting as a pharmacogenomic marker in colorectal cancer.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: The SNP rs1985157 was associated with neutrophil count and neutrophil percentage and was assigned to the LRRC25 gene through TWAS, despite coloc not attributing it to any gene. The significant correlation of rs1985157 with LRRC25's predicted expression indicated its role in innate immune response and autophagy.
title: Transcriptome-wide association study in UK Biobank Europeans identifies associations with blood cell traits

finding: In the context of the AK3 locus for platelet traits (Plt), the missense variant rs7412 was in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs1065853, and was captured only by FINEMAP-inf.
title: Improving fine-mapping by modeling infinitesimal effects

finding: The variant rs1065853 was identified alongside rs429358 by SuSiE, SuSiE-inf, and FINEMAP-inf as a known causal variant at the AK3 locus associated with platelet traits (Plt).
title: Improving fine-mapping by modeling infinitesimal effects

finding: The variant rs429358 was also captured at the AK3 locus for Plt by SuSiE-inf and FINEMAP-inf, indicating its established role as a causal variant.
title: Improving fine-mapping by modeling infinitesimal effects

finding: The variant rs429358, located in the APOE gene, was significantly associated with plasma Aβ1-42 levels and the Aβ1-42/Aβ1-40 ratio, with p-values of 9.01×10^-13 and 6.46×10^-20, respectively. The minor allele, associated with APOE ε4, correlated with lower levels of plasma Aβ1-42 (effect size = -0.167 SD, 95% CI = [-0.212; -0.121]) and a lower Aβ1-42/Aβ1-40 ratio (effect size = -0.212 SD, 95% CI = [-0.257; -0.121]). These findings were confirmed using directly genotyped APOE ε4 status.
title: Plasma amyloid β levels are driven by genetic variants near APOE, BACE1, APP, PSEN2: A genome-wide association study in over 12,000 non-demented participants

finding: The SNP rs1555735545 was associated with Limb-girdle muscular dystrophy and was found in the ORF CATP00000063293.1. It was noted that this SNP, annotated as an Intron/5' UTR variant, changed the start codon of the encoded protein from ATG to ATA. The study provided strong PhyloCSF signal (88.6) applying an ORF-origin-aware method and a very high phenotypic score (69) in K562 cells, indicating its potential functional role.
title: De novo birth of functional, human-specific microproteins

finding: The SNP rs3865444 was associated with the Siglec-3 protein, which is linked to Alzheimer's disease risk. This finding highlighted a potential avenue for understanding links between midlife obesity and late-life Alzheimer's risk, suggesting its importance as a prognostic biomarker.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The SNP rs2227376 caused a C to T base substitution leading to an amino acid change from proline to leucine at position 310, resulting in reduced PAR4 signaling and decreased platelet activation. This variant was associated with a 15% risk reduction in venous thromboembolism (VTE). The research utilized a mouse model with a homologous mutation (PAR4-P322L) to validate these effects, demonstrating impaired platelet activation, reduced incidence and size of venous clots, and decreased thrombin generation.
title: Mice with Reduced PAR4 Reactivity show Decreased Venous Thrombosis and Platelet Procoagulant Activity

finding: rs681343 was associated with peptic ulcer disease (PUD) and was found to be statistically significant in both UKB discovery and GERA replication GWAS studies. It was located in the FUT2 gene, which has an established role in susceptibility to Helicobacter pylori infection.
title: Genome-wide association study of gastrointestinal disorders reinforces the link between the digestive tract and the nervous system

finding: rs12462498 was associated with GP+M and had previously established links to Barrett's esophagus and esophageal adenocarcinoma, contributing to the understanding of genetic factors in these conditions.
title: Genome-wide association study of gastrointestinal disorders reinforces the link between the digestive tract and the nervous system

finding: This SNP was associated with the ratio of STK11/USP8 with a high statistical significance (p=-log10(13.8), p-gain=10.5). The SNP was located in the intragenic region of the STK11 gene and was linked to the presence versus absence of psychosis in Alzheimer’s disease cases. This finding suggested a role for STK11 in Alzheimer's pathology and provided insights into potential therapeutic targets.
title: Genetic associations with ratios between protein levels detect new pQTLs and reveal protein-protein interactions

finding: This SNP was associated with a significant ratio between LDLR and PCSK9 (p-gain=67.2). It is in linkage disequilibrium (LD) with coding SNP rs7412 in APOE. The study highlighted that PCSK9 binds to LDLR, targeting it for degradation, thus implicating this ratio in lipid metabolism and cardiovascular health.
title: Genetic associations with ratios between protein levels detect new pQTLs and reveal protein-protein interactions

finding: The SNP rs1064395 in the Ncan gene was associated with an increased risk for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It correlated with behavioral abnormalities such as hyperactivity in both humans and Ncan knockout mice, as highlighted in the findings from Miro et al. (2012). Further evidence showed that the presence of this risk variant resulted in impaired hippocampus-dependent memory functions and variation in prefrontal cortex structure and extracellular matrix composition, validating the role of this SNP in cognitive deficits observed in neuropsychiatric disorders.
title: Depletion of neurocan in the prefrontal cortex impairs temporal order recognition, cognitive flexibility and perisomatic GABAergic innervation

finding: The SNP rs7412 was associated with Apolipoprotein E haplotype status in the study population, which categorized individuals into three groups based on cognitive impairment status: cognitively normal, early mild cognitive impairment (eMCI), and mild cognitive impairment (MCI). This association was significant for the tracking of cognitive decline.
title: Free-water metrics in medial temporal lobe white matter tract projections relate to longitudinal cognitive decline

finding: The SNP rs429358 was also linked to Apolipoprotein E haplotype status among participants, which played a role in determining the cognitive categories (cognitively normal, eMCI, and MCI) and was pivotal in monitoring cognitive decline over the study period.
title: Free-water metrics in medial temporal lobe white matter tract projections relate to longitudinal cognitive decline

finding: The SNP rs3729836 was identified at the upstream 3' splice site of human TNNI3 exon 3. It was found to decrease the 3' MaxEnt splice score from 4.26 to 3.69, which lowered the likelihood of exon 3 inclusion to approximately 57%. This SNP also disrupted the branch point consensus sequence in the pre-mRNA, indicating a predisposition to alternative splicing. It was reported with a common frequency of 35.1% in gnomAD and 37.8% in TOPMed, highlighting its potential impact on the splicing efficiency of TNNI3 exon 3 in humans.
title: Genetic excision of the regulatory cardiac troponin I extension in high heart rate mammal clades

finding: The SNP rs3865444 in the huCD33 promoter was associated with the expression of two isoforms: CD33M, which contains the ligand binding V-set domain, and D2-CD33, which lacks this domain. This finding highlighted the role of this SNP in regulating the alternative splicing of CD33 and its implications for immune responses.
title: Evolution of Human-specific Alleles Protecting Cognitive Function of Grandmothers

finding: Similar to rs3865444, the SNP rs12459419 located within exon 2 was implicated in alternative splicing affecting the functionality of the CD33 protein. This was significant for understanding how CD33 variants may influence immune responses and cognitive health.
title: Evolution of Human-specific Alleles Protecting Cognitive Function of Grandmothers

finding: The minor allele of rs212100 showed an association with lower plasma levels of SULT2A1 and reduced gallstone risk, with these variants serving as robust cis pQTLs across different platforms.
title: Large-scale comparison of immunoassay- and aptamer-based plasma proteomics through genetics and disease

finding: For the variant rs116843064 in ANGPTL4, an association with HDL-C levels was established, corroborating results from previous studies associating ANGPTL4 with lipid profiles.
title: Role of Rare and Low Frequency Variants in Gene-Alcohol Interactions on Plasma Lipid Levels

finding: The SNP rs549267286 was found to be part of a cluster of four consecutive missense SNPs in the LILRB3 gene, which exhibited a strong association with death censored graft loss (DCGL) among African American kidney transplant recipients. This SNP encoded a missense mutation impacting amino acids 617-618, which are proximal to an SHP-1/2 phosphatase-binding motif, and showed significantly higher prevalence in African Americans compared to other populations.
title: Genetic polymorphisms of Leukocyte Immunoglobulin-Like Receptor B3 (LILRB3) gene in African American kidney transplant recipients are associated with post-transplant graft failure

finding: SNP rs139094141 was identified as part of the 'LILRB3-4SNPs' cluster that was significantly associated with DCGL. This missense mutation affected amino acids 617-618 in the LILRB3 gene and was linked to enhanced adaptive immune responses in kidney transplant recipients.
title: Genetic polymorphisms of Leukocyte Immunoglobulin-Like Receptor B3 (LILRB3) gene in African American kidney transplant recipients are associated with post-transplant graft failure

finding: The SNP rs567676351 was included in the LILRB3-4SNPs cluster, which was strongly associated with graft loss in African American kidney transplant recipients. Its presence indicated alterations in immune response mechanisms due to the missense mutation.
title: Genetic polymorphisms of Leukocyte Immunoglobulin-Like Receptor B3 (LILRB3) gene in African American kidney transplant recipients are associated with post-transplant graft failure

finding: SNP rs761515451 was part of the cluster of four SNPs in the LILRB3 gene associated with DCGL. It contributed to the altered phenotype of immune responses in individuals of African American descent undergoing kidney transplantation.
title: Genetic polymorphisms of Leukocyte Immunoglobulin-Like Receptor B3 (LILRB3) gene in African American kidney transplant recipients are associated with post-transplant graft failure

finding: The SNP rs429358 within the APOE gene was identified as a significant Q finding connected to cognitive aging, particularly regarding its association with general factor of intelligence (g). It exhibited a notable pattern of associations with cognitive traits closely aligned with the genetic g factor but demonstrated a null association with VNR, a measure showing minimal age-related differences.
title: Genetic “General Intelligence,” Objectively Determined and Measured

finding: The SNP rs10524523 was shown to be located in intron 6 of the TOMM40 gene, and linked to a T STR associated with CAGE signal in various FANTOM libraries. This variant was connected to the age of onset of cognitive decline and Alzheimer's disease, along with sporadic inclusion body myositis. The findings indicated that longer T STR variants corresponded to higher TOMM40 mRNA expression in the brain.
title: Evidence of transcription at polyT short tandem repeats

finding: The SNP rs429358 was associated with the ε3 and ε4 alleles of the APOE gene. It played a significant role in determining the risk for Alzheimer disease (AD), with the ε4 allele being a known risk factor for the development of AD.
title: Interaction of sortilin with apolipoprotein E3 enables neurons to use long-chain fatty acids as alternative metabolic fuel

finding: The research showcased a significant association between the informative SNP rs2014377 located in exon 3 of SIX5 and allele-specific gene expression, particularly in the context of Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1). Prior to gene editing, an expression imbalance was noted in unmanipulated DM1 hESCs with a ratio showing the normal allele favored at 0.43. Post-gene editing, the allele imbalance was corrected, yielding a difference of 1.2 to 1.3 in favor of the alleles from which the CTG repeat expansion was excised. This was interpreted as demethylation upstream of the excised repeat leading to a rescue of SIX5 transcription, addressing haploinsufficiency posited in DM1 pathology.
title: Deletion of the CTG Expansion in Myotonic Dystrophy Type 1 Reverses DMPK Aberrant Methylation in Human Embryonic Stem Cells but not Affected Myoblasts

finding: The analysis involving SNP rs635299 permitted an insightful distinction between normal and expanded alleles during the allele-specific methylation analysis within the DMPK locus. Following the deletion of the CTG repeat in myoblast clones, methylation levels were invariant, consistently showing 100% methylation in all clones carrying the expanded allele (T variant). This finding underscored the stable methylation associated with the mutant allele even post-editing, reinforcing the notion that in differentiated cells, such as myoblasts, epigenetic changes induced by large repeat expansions were irreversible and maintained despite gene editing attempts.
title: Deletion of the CTG Expansion in Myotonic Dystrophy Type 1 Reverses DMPK Aberrant Methylation in Human Embryonic Stem Cells but not Affected Myoblasts

finding: The TM6SF2 rs58542926 gene polymorphism was linked with the risk of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and colorectal adenoma, indicating significant implications for colorectal cancer.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP rs10402271, located within an intergenic region between the BCAM and PVRL2 genes, was found to be significant in the analysis of LDL, replicating two out of four associated SNPs.
title: Multi-scale Inference of Genetic Trait Architecture using Biologically Annotated Neural Networks

finding: The SNP rs4804833 was linked to the gene MAP2K7 located on human chromosome 19. The corresponding mouse homologue engaged in a cluster 9 DInt, corroborating previous findings from GWAS studies regarding its association with obesity.
title: Genome-wide analysis of promoter contacts identifies novel regulators of late-stage adipogenesis

finding: This SNP was linked to multiple sclerosis and was shown to exhibit increased accessibility and contact with the promoters of the GPR108 and TRIP10 genes 8 hours post T cell activation. The expression of these genes was also increased at this time, making it a significant finding in the context of autoimmune disease research.
title: Dynamic chromatin architecture identifies new autoimmune-associated enhancers for IL2 and novel genes regulating CD4+ T cell activation

finding: The TYK2 variant showed significant negative selection attributed to tuberculosis risks, with estimates indicating selection over the last 2,000 years due to increasing pressures from Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
title: Deep estimation of the intensity and timing of selection from ancient genomes

finding: The SNP rs9973235 was associated with a non-synonymous polymorphism in the protein Perilipin-3. This polymorphism was identified through mass spectrometry analysis using the MetaNovo/UniProt software pipeline on the SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cell-line samples. The peptide corresponding to rs9973235 displayed a 100.0% sequence identity with the orthologous protein from Macaca mulatta, indicating its relevance to human variation and its previous identification in a proteogenomic study of the same cell line.
title: MetaNovo: a probabilistic approach to peptide and polymorphism discovery in complex mass spectrometry datasets

finding: The SNP rs429358 was identified as a pathogenic variant associated with the APOE-ε4 allele, which infers an increased risk of Alzheimer's Disease. This increased risk was noted across various ancestries, including European and African populations. The allele frequency (AF) for rs429358 was found to be high, which was expected due to its association with Alzheimer's Disease. The study discussed the observed heterogeneity in its effect size and allele frequency across different ancestries.
title: Summix: A method for detecting and adjusting for population structure in genetic summary data

finding: The SNP rs483082 was linked to the APOC1 gene and showed significant association with increased TG/HDL (p < 10-48). It was part of an epistatic interaction with rs1800775, suggesting that these SNPs act in an opposing manner to modulate the TG/HDL phenotype.
title: Mechanistic genotype-phenotype translation using hierarchical transformers

finding: The SNP rs58542926 was significantly associated with liver fat, in line with previous findings linking it to NAFLD, demonstrating its role in liver health.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs429358 had a significant association with liver fat and has been previously reported in connection to NAFLD and lipid metabolism traits.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs188247550 was associated with liver fat and previously linked to hyperlipidemia and alcohol-induced cirrhosis, highlighting its clinical importance.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The SNP rs10422861 was associated with pancreatic fat and linked to several body composition metrics, suggesting a role in metabolic health.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: Similar to rs10278, rs2289865 on chromosome 19 was also identified by the univariate gge test for HDL. It was also not an independent locus due to being in LD with other significant SNPs.
title: A multivariate approach to joint testing of main genetic and gene-environment interaction effects

finding: The SNP CLEC4M/rs12610506-G decreased in frequency from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America, indicating a role in the regional genetic susceptibility to Zika congenital complications.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The SNP CD209/rs4804801-T also decreased in frequency from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America, reflecting its potential impact on Zika virus susceptibility.
title: Hypothetical Human Immune Genome Complex Gradient May Help to Explain the Congenital Zika Symdrome Catastrophe in Brazil: A New Theory

finding: The study provided significant evidence that the APOE epsilon 4 allele, specifically represented by the rs429358 SNP, served as a primary genetic risk factor for late onset Alzheimer's disease. However, upon further analysis considering future diagnoses, the previously observed effects on hippocampal volume were attributed to prodromal changes linked to mild cognitive impairment rather than direct genetic influence.
title: APOE ε4 effects on hippocampal atrophy in the healthy elderly reflect future cognitive decline

finding: The rs7412 SNP was also investigated in relation to its role as a genetic risk factor for Alzheimer's disease, showing that the presence of the APOE epsilon 4 allele, as determined by this SNP, correlated with cognitive and neuroimaging changes. Nevertheless, similar to rs429358, the effects observed were not directly due to genotype but rather were influenced by eventual diagnoses of prodromal mild cognitive impairment.
title: APOE ε4 effects on hippocampal atrophy in the healthy elderly reflect future cognitive decline

finding: The rs7412 SNP was analyzed as part of the APOE genotype determination, where it was associated with the E4 allele. In individuals carrying the E4 allele, metabolic rewiring was observed, characterized by increased aerobic glycolysis and decreased oxidative phosphorylation in astrocytes, which relates to cerebral glucose hypometabolism and represents a significant finding in the context of early Alzheimer’s disease pathology.
title: APOE4 Lowers Energy Expenditure and Impairs Glucose Oxidation by Increasing Flux through Aerobic Glycolysis

finding: The rs429358 SNP was also integral in determining the APOE genotype, linking it to the E4 allele. Carriers of this allele demonstrated a metabolic phenotype consistent with reduced energy expenditure and increased lactate levels in plasma, evidencing a shift to aerobic glycolysis which is a key factor in the preclinical stages of Alzheimer’s disease.
title: APOE4 Lowers Energy Expenditure and Impairs Glucose Oxidation by Increasing Flux through Aerobic Glycolysis

finding: The rs7412 variant was associated with LDL lipid levels in models generated from both FINEMAP and flashfm approaches. It was notably highlighted as an important missense variant (Arg158Cys) influencing type III hyperlipoproteinemia, which is characterized by hyperlipidemia leading to susceptibility to coronary artery disease. Additionally, this SNP was recognized for its impact on the efficacy of atorvastatin, a medication used to lower cardiovascular risk.
title: Flashfm: A Flexible and Shared Information Fine-mapping Approach for Multiple Quantitative Traits

finding: The rs429358 variant was identified as a key factor associated with LDL cholesterol levels. In the context of the APOE gene, it along with rs7412 defined the ε-alleles which are crucial in lipid metabolism. It was confirmed as the only SNP within group L in the top models for LDL and total cholesterol (TC) using both FINEMAP and flashfm.
title: Flashfm: A Flexible and Shared Information Fine-mapping Approach for Multiple Quantitative Traits

finding: The rs75627662 SNP was selected as the top candidate SNP for HDL cholesterol in flashfm analysis, although it showed a much weaker association compared to other lipid traits such as LDL and TC. It was indicated as an intergenic SNP located upstream of the APOE gene.
title: Flashfm: A Flexible and Shared Information Fine-mapping Approach for Multiple Quantitative Traits

finding: The study identified that rs2251034 (A>G, 3' UTR) in the FUT2 gene was negatively associated with three study-wide significant peptides that belonged to Norwalk virus polyproteins. This association was supported due to the variant's high linkage with an early-stop variant in FUT2, which is known to halt the secretion of the H-antigen, a crucial factor for the virus's attachment to host cells. Thus, it reinforced previous findings linking FUT2 secretor status to Norwalk virus susceptibility.
title: Genetic, environmental and intrinsic determinants of the human antibody epitope repertoire

finding: The rs601338 (A>G) variant was shown to be in high linkage with rs2251034 and was associated with the FUT2 gene's ability to secrete the H-antigen. The loss of function due to this variant was previously linked to multiple phenotypes, including infection susceptibility among other traits, affirming its relevance in the immunity landscape.
title: Genetic, environmental and intrinsic determinants of the human antibody epitope repertoire

finding: The finding related to the XRCC1 gene polymorphism Arg194Trp (rs1799782, C>T) showed a significant association with bladder cancer. This SNP, located in exon 6, was linked to patients who had experienced single-strand DNA breaks, which may indicate a higher susceptibility to cancer.
title: Association of Metabolic and DNA-repair gene polymorphisms with Longevity: a role for GSTT1, GSTP and XPC genes

finding: The Arg280His polymorphism (rs25489, A>G) in the XRCC1 gene was also associated with bladder cancer. The evidence suggested that this SNP could affect DNA repair mechanisms and thus influence an individual's cancer risk.
title: Association of Metabolic and DNA-repair gene polymorphisms with Longevity: a role for GSTT1, GSTP and XPC genes

finding: The SNP rs7412 was positively associated with LDL levels, replicating findings observed in the UK biobank for this lipid trait.
title: Understanding Complex Trait Susceptibilities and Ethnical Diversity in a Sample of 4,145 Russians Through Analysis of Clinical and Genetic Data

finding: The SNP rs74800719 passed the Bonferroni-adjusted replication threshold and was associated with an increased risk of Alzheimer disease and apolipoprotein B levels in the Russian cohort, reflecting its strong linkage to these phenotypes.
title: Understanding Complex Trait Susceptibilities and Ethnical Diversity in a Sample of 4,145 Russians Through Analysis of Clinical and Genetic Data

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with the risk of overall breast cancer, indicating a potential link between vitamin B12 concentrations and breast cancer.
title: Circulating concentrations of micro-nutrients and risk of breast cancer: A Mendelian randomization study

finding: This SNP corresponded to a stop lost mutation in the PSPN gene (persephin neurothropic factor), which has implications in neurodevelopment, reflecting its significance in gene expression regulation related to clinical conditions.
title: Derived Homo sapiens cis-eQTL regulation: implications for brain evolution

finding: The AD risk allele APOE E4 was identified in cell line NCRM1, contributing to its risk profile for Alzheimer's Disease.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: The AD risk allele APOE E4 was identified in cell line NCRM5, supporting its association with Alzheimer's Disease risk.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: In the context of gene editing using Prime Editing (PE) in human induced pluripotent stem (iPS) cells, the rs429358 SNP, associated with the apolipoprotein (APOE) gene, was successfully engineered to change the APOE3 variant to the APOE4 genotype. The correct editing rate for this SNP was estimated at 23.6% in the high mCherry expression fraction, validated by droplet digital PCR (ddPCR) yielding 21.3% correct edits. This demonstrates a significant advancement in the precision of gene editing methods at medically relevant loci.
title: Enrichment of allelic editing outcomes by Prime Editing in iPS cells

finding: The SNP rs112837068 was identified as the top SNV for a genome-wide significant landmark-delaying modifier effect (19BM1) at the POLD1 gene, associated with age at TFC6 (p=6.6E-10) but not with age at motor onset (p=5.1E-04). This finding indicated its role in modifying disease progression.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs3218772 was indicated as a missense variant tagging a second landmark-delaying effect (19BM2) at POLD1 that showed suggestive significance for both age at TFC6 and motor onset (p=3.4E-06 and 3.1E-06 respectively). It illustrated the influence of genetic variation on clinical landmarks.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs145821638 played a significant role as a missense variant in LIG1, contributing to the profound genetic influence on Huntington's disease.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The SNP rs3078205 displayed notable findings connected to LIG1, facilitating an understanding of its association with disease modifiers.
title: Genetic modifiers of somatic expansion and clinical phenotypes in Huntington’s disease reveal shared and tissue-specific effects

finding: The variant rs3093105, designated as CYP4F2*2, was found to have a frequency of approximately 40% in the Fulani and Hausa ethnolinguistic groups. This SNP was associated with altered warfarin sensitivity and metabolism, demonstrating pharmacogenomic relevance in these cohorts compared to lower frequencies observed in the Yoruba population, which was closer to 30%.
title: Whole-genome sequencing across 449 samples spanning 47 ethnolinguistic groups provides insights into genetic diversity in Nigeria

finding: The polymorphism rs2108622, designated as CYP4F2*3, exhibited elevated frequencies in the Fulani and Hausa ELGs (15-17%) compared to approximately 5% in Yoruban individuals. This SNP was associated with reduced enzymatic levels of cytochrome P450 4F2 crucial for the metabolism of vitamin K and implicated in warfarin response, specifically noted in studies concerning European and Han-Chinese populations.
title: Whole-genome sequencing across 449 samples spanning 47 ethnolinguistic groups provides insights into genetic diversity in Nigeria

finding: The SNP rs7412 was identified as the single most significant SNV for LDL-C, exhibiting a P-value less than 1.0x10^-316. Functional predictions using MACIE-protein and MACIE-conserved scores were both over 0.95, indicating that it had multiple functional roles.
title: A multi-dimensional integrative scoring framework for predicting functional variants in the human genome

finding: This SNP was the second most significant SNV linked to LDL-C with a P-value less than 1.0x10^-316 and was in high linkage disequilibrium with rs7412. The MACIE-regulatory score was greater than 0.99, suggesting a regulatory role in affecting LDL-C levels.
title: A multi-dimensional integrative scoring framework for predicting functional variants in the human genome

finding: The SNP rs429358 was associated with blood lipid, blood protein, inflammation, and cognitive decline. It was categorized as an outlier in the analysis of self-reported physical activity with overall lung cancer, squamous cell carcinoma, small cell carcinoma, and lung cancer in ever smokers, although its removal did not alter MR estimates.
title: Physical activity and risk of lung cancer: a two-sample Mendelian randomization study

finding: The intronic variant rs184528844 was identified within the CEACAM1-LIPE-AS1 haplotype in Oceanic groups, demonstrating an archaic-like branching event, despite appearing after the split of archaic hominins and modern humans.
title: Exploring adaptive introgression in modern human circadian rhythm genes

finding: The rs35081008 variant generated a HIC2 repressor site that decreased expression of ZNF329, demonstrating a distinct causal pathway for this regulatory effect.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The rs34003091 variant disrupted an HNF1 activator motif, specifically in HepG2 cells. Its impact on transcriptional activity was substantial and different from that seen with rs35081008.
title: Functional dissection of complex and molecular trait variants at single nucleotide resolution

finding: The SNP rs7412 in the APOE gene showed a highly significant association with the binary trait of high cholesterol, as indicated by a p-value of 1.640e-19, in a GWAS that accounted for covariates. It was flagged for follow-up studies to investigate its non-additive effects related to latent GxE interactions.
title: Detecting latent gene-environment interaction when analyzing binary traits

finding: The SNP rs7254892 mapped to NECTIN2 exhibited a significant interaction with rs7412, with the smallest p-value of the interaction test recorded at 1.713e-07. It was part of an analysis aimed at identifying interactions with nearby SNPs, indicating its importance in the GxG context.
title: Detecting latent gene-environment interaction when analyzing binary traits

finding: The SNP rs429358 is part of the haplotypes defined by the APOE gene, in combination with rs7412, which are known to influence cholesterol levels. It was included in the GxG analysis indicating the relevant linkage to rs7412 in the study of interaction effects.
title: Detecting latent gene-environment interaction when analyzing binary traits

finding: The SNP rs7412 was associated with the presence of the APOE e4 allele, which has implications for increased risk of cognitive decline. This finding related to cognitive ability measurements in older adults and highlighted the relevance of APOE genotype in understanding age-related cognitive changes.
title: Three major dimensions of human brain cortical ageing in relation to cognitive decline across the 8th decade of life

finding: The SNP rs429358 was also identified as a critical variant contributing to the APOE e4 allele status. This SNP's association with cognitive decline was evidenced in longitudinal studies, emphasizing the genetic influence on cortical atrophy and cognitive performance in the aging population.
title: Three major dimensions of human brain cortical ageing in relation to cognitive decline across the 8th decade of life

finding: The SNP rs601338, located in the FUT2 gene, was positively associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), particularly celiac disease and Crohn's disease in the Finnish population, based on a study by Parmar et al. in 2012. This finding suggested that variations in the FUT2 gene could influence susceptibility to these immune-mediated disorders.
title: Specific norovirus interaction with Lewis x and Lewis a on human intestinal inflammatory mucosa during refractory inflammatory bowel disease

finding: The SNP rs35866622, located in the FUT1/FUT2 locus, was strongly associated with the abundance of Ruminococcus torques (p=2.21×10⁻⁸). It is a proxy for the functional variant rs601338, which impacts the synthesis of fucosylated mucus glycans in the gastrointestinal tract and has shown to correlate with dietary habits, particularly fruit intake.
title: Large-scale association analyses identify host factors influencing human gut microbiome composition

finding: The SNP rs1683587 was associated with reticulocyte counts as part of a broader analysis involving rare CNVs and other variants at the R3HDM4 locus. It was noted that this intronic SNP likely contributed to regulatory functions in the first intron of R3HDM4.
title: Influences of rare copy number variation on human complex traits

finding: rs737337 showed uniformly positive associations with M-HDL-P, L-HDL-P, XL-HDL-P, HDL-D, ApoA1, and HDL-C, while exhibiting a negative association with coronary artery disease (CAD). This indicated its role in favorably influencing the lipid profile associated with reduced CAD risk.
title: A Mendelian randomization study of the role of lipoprotein subfractions in coronary artery disease

finding: The study identified a 44 bp deletion in exon 14 of ABCA7 (rs142076058, p.Arg578 fs) using the Scalpel variant calling tool. This pathogenic deletion was subsequently linked to Alzheimer's disease (AD) in African American populations during further investigation involving a larger sample.
title: A comparative study of structural variant calling strategies using the Alzheimer’s Disease Sequencing Project’s whole genome family data

finding: This SNP was found to be under positive selection in the Kinh population, functioning as an eQTL for CYP4F12 in adipose tissue, which suggests regulatory implications in metabolic pathways.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: It was established that rs62115147 was under positive selection, associated with expression levels of CYP4F3 in brain and nerve tissues, indicating its relevance in neurological contexts.
title: Signatures of co-evolution and co-regulation in the CYP3A and CYP4F genes in humans

finding: The SNP rs344812 was identified as a risk variant that increased MARK4 expression in the cortex, with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.14, indicating its significant role in Alzheimer's disease risk.
title: Immediate-Early Genes as Influencers in Genetic Networks and their Role in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was classified as protective with a minor allele frequency less than 5%, but its specific effects on AD were underexplored, hence contributing to its significance.
title: Immediate-Early Genes as Influencers in Genetic Networks and their Role in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: Like rs149628060, this SNP was a rare protective variant with very low MAF, and while previously unreported, it highlighted the need for further investigation into its role in Alzheimer's disease.
title: Immediate-Early Genes as Influencers in Genetic Networks and their Role in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The variant rs1800437 (p.Glu354Gln) in GIPR was associated with multiple phenotypes, including fresh fruit intake (p=4.2×10⁻⁹, β=0.017, 95% CI: 0.011-0.023) and body size phenotypes. The study demonstrated that this variant led to blunted signaling in various pathways, indicating a potential mechanism for its association with food intake and body size.
title: Medical relevance of common protein-altering variants in GPCR genes across 337,205 individuals in the UK Biobank

finding: This SNP, crucial for determining the allele type of APOE, was successfully identified as a significant genetic factor in Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: This SNP, combined with rs429358, was recognized for its crucial role in APOE genetics, reinforcing its strong association with increased risk of Alzheimer's disease.
title: GenEpi: Gene-based Epistasis Discovery Using Machine Learning

finding: The SNP rs772794650 corresponds to the I91M mutation, which was identified as important for hCEACAM1 IgV homodimerization. Mutations in this area weakened the homodimerization affinity, leading to decreased stability as shown by a lower thermal denaturation temperature. This mutation's impact was further supported by studies demonstrating that variants exhibited melting temperatures suggestive of their stability in both monomeric and dimeric forms.
title: Structural basis of the dynamic human CEACAM1 monomer-dimer equilibrium

finding: The SNP rs1335884800 relates to the N97T mutation, which was analyzed alongside other mutations for its role in dimerization behavior. Although the specific effects were not detailed individually, the overall findings indicated that alterations at this position affected the stability and homodimerization capability of hCEACAM1, thereby correlating with variations in thermal denaturation temperature.
title: Structural basis of the dynamic human CEACAM1 monomer-dimer equilibrium

finding: The SNP rs142826356 refers to the E99G mutation, which, like the others, was shown to alter the dimerization characteristics of hCEACAM1. It was part of the comparative analysis that correlated changes in homodimerization affinity with thermal stability, indicating that mutations in this region could lead to destabilization of homodimer formation, thus affecting protein function.
title: Structural basis of the dynamic human CEACAM1 monomer-dimer equilibrium

finding: The SNP rs62128466, found in the PCSK4 gene, was deemed highly important across both exome+metabolome and exome+metabolome+phenome datasets. Its extremely low minor allele frequency of 0.00003, combined with its high expression in the thalamus, suggests it could significantly influence the diagnosis and development of developmental dyslexia.
title: A data-fusion approach to identifying developmental dyslexia from multi-omics datasets

finding: The SNP rs11668477 at the LDLR locus was reported with a significant P-value of 0.0002, indicating its association with SM16:0 in earlier lipid trait GWAS studies. This SNP was also previously linked to LDL-C and total cholesterol levels, underscoring its relevance in lipid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The SNP rs73001065 near the MAU2 gene was found to be suggestively associated with PC34:4. Although this SNP was not present in earlier GWAS datasets, its strong linkage disequilibrium with rs3794991 (R²=0.81), which associated significantly with PC34:4, supports the relevance of this locus in lipid metabolism.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The SNP rs3794991 was strongly associated with the lipid species PC34:4, with a P-value of 7.4 x 10^-5 in the analysis that excluded duplicate samples from the EUROSPAN dataset. This finding was important in validating the link between lipid metabolism and genetic variants.
title: Genome-wide association study of plasma triglycerides, phospholipids and relation to cardio-metabolic risk factors

finding: The lead SNP rs1465697 (chr19:49837246 C>T) was identified as a significant association with multiple sclerosis (MS) genetics, having a p-value of 3.02x10^-18. It was prioritized in statistical fine-mapping, showing a posterior probability (PP) of 15% among the credible set of SNPs for this locus. The SNP was linked to chromatin accessibility overlapping with CD4 T and B cells, indicating its potential role as a causal variant. Additionally, it was shown to be an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) specifically for the gene TEAD2 in B cells, highlighting its relevance in shared cellular mechanisms in MS pathogenesis.
title: Dissection of multiple sclerosis genetics identifies B and CD4+ T cells as driver cell subsets

finding: The SNP rs429358, related to the Apolipoprotein E (APOE) gene, was investigated and found to correlate with cognitive performance measures, particularly in individuals classified as APOE-ε4 carriers. Carriers exhibited lower beta peak frequencies in resting EEG measures, suggesting an association with cognitive decline.
title: Resting EEG power spectra across middle to late life: Associations with age, cognition, APOE-ε4 carriage and cardiometabolic burden

finding: The SNP rs7412 was analyzed alongside rs429358 and identified to have been part of the classification for APOE-ε4 carrier status. The findings indicated that carriers of this variant, as well as rs429358, had lower beta peak frequencies in EEG, linking these genetic factors directly with potential cognitive decline.
title: Resting EEG power spectra across middle to late life: Associations with age, cognition, APOE-ε4 carriage and cardiometabolic burden

finding: The SNP rs75621460 was highlighted as a likely causal risk variant for osteoarthritis. It resided within a cCRE primarily open in immune cell types and was predicted to target the immunosuppressive cytokine gene TGFB1. Importantly, this variant disrupted a binding site for the zinc-finger transcription factor ERG1, which could impact the regulatory landscape of immune responses.
title: A cell atlas of chromatin accessibility across 25 adult human tissues

finding: The analysis of the rs7412 SNP, part of the APOE genotype, was associated with diagnostic classification in Alzheimer's disease (AD). The SNP was determined using a combination of Affymetrix and TaqMan assays, which helped in establishing its relevance to AD biomarker criteria.
title: Multi-Platform Proteomic Analysis of Alzheimer’s Disease Cerebrospinal Fluid and Plasma Reveals Network Biomarkers Associated with Proteostasis and the Matrisome

finding: The rs429358 SNP, also part of the APOE genotype, was examined in conjunction with the rs7412 SNP for their influence on AD diagnosis. Both SNPs were found valuable for supporting diagnostic classifications based on AD biomarker cutoff criteria.
title: Multi-Platform Proteomic Analysis of Alzheimer’s Disease Cerebrospinal Fluid and Plasma Reveals Network Biomarkers Associated with Proteostasis and the Matrisome

finding: The sentinel variant rs7412 in the APOE gene region demonstrated a highly significant association with a P value of 7.1×10^-55. This variant was part of a region where additional common variants were also significantly associated, with P values below 5×10^-8. After conditioning on this variant, a secondary association was identified.
title: StocSum: stochastic summary statistics for whole genome sequencing studies

finding: The secondary association variant rs429358 in the APOE gene region had a conditional P value of 8.2×10^-15 after conditioning on the sentinel variant rs7412. This finding indicated its significance alongside rs7412 in the context of their associations.
title: StocSum: stochastic summary statistics for whole genome sequencing studies

finding: The SNP rs6857 at the APOE locus exhibited a significant association with inferred disease stage in the Mayo Clinic cohort, with a p-value of 9.18 x 10^-6. APOE has been previously established as a major risk factor for Alzheimer's disease.
title: Molecular estimation of neurodegeneration pseudotime in older brains

finding: The SNP rs429358 was identified as a proximal mod-QTL for the M42 matrisome module, which is significantly enriched for AD risk genes. This finding indicated that the expression level of the M42 module was influenced by APOE genotype, particularly the presence of the APOE epsilon 4 allele. The analysis revealed that M42 was the only module that varied by APOE genotype, highlighting its critical role in Alzheimer's disease pathology.
title: Large-Scale Deep Multi-Layer Analysis of Alzheimer’s Disease Brain Reveals Strong Proteomic Disease-Related Changes Not Observed at the RNA Level

finding: SNP rs10412176 was involved in increased surface area in the temporal pole for BD, further illustrating its genetic relevance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs55765017 showed connections with diminished SA and CT in primary sensory cortices for both BD and SCZ, illustrating its impact.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: SNP rs55931635 was linked to decreased SA and CT in primary cortical areas for both BD and SCZ, highlighting its genetic importance.
title: The overlapping genetic architecture of psychiatric disorders and cortical brain structure

finding: This SNP, similar to rs124594919, was linked to a reduced risk of Alzheimer's Disease (AD). It was also identified as a functional variant that contributes to an increased proportion of D2-CD33, suggesting a relationship between this SNP and altered CD33 function.
title: Pseudogene-mediated gene conversion after CRISPR-Cas9 editing demonstrated by partial CD33 conversion with SIGLEC22P

finding: This SNP was associated with missense mutations in the KIR-CD33 isoform, which resulted from gene conversion from the SIGLEC22P pseudogene. It exhibited an identical minor allele frequency alongside similar SNPs in KIR-CD33.
title: Pseudogene-mediated gene conversion after CRISPR-Cas9 editing demonstrated by partial CD33 conversion with SIGLEC22P

finding: This SNP also contributed to the KIR-CD33 variant, resulting in changes to amino acids that are crucial for protein function, indicating potential relevance of these mutations in clinical contexts.
title: Pseudogene-mediated gene conversion after CRISPR-Cas9 editing demonstrated by partial CD33 conversion with SIGLEC22P

finding: This SNP, like the others in the KIR-CD33 editing, was part of the three missense mutations leading to significant changes in amino acids, reinforcing its role in the impact of CD33 function.
title: Pseudogene-mediated gene conversion after CRISPR-Cas9 editing demonstrated by partial CD33 conversion with SIGLEC22P

finding: The SNP rs1122608, located in intron 29 of the SMARCA4 gene, was identified as having significant evidence for association with SMARCA4 expression levels across various tissues. This finding underscored its role as an independent genetic risk factor for atherosclerosis, as the expression of SMARCA4 was noted to be influenced by this SNP.
title: Hemin-driven chromatin remodelling by atherosclerotic risk gene SMARCA4 switches human blood-derived macrophages from leukocyte disposal to erythrocyte disposal

finding: The SNP rs117961479 was found to have a genome-wide significant association with cholesterol (CHOL) levels in the HCHS/SoL cohort, indicated by a pJ value of 1.5×10^-9. This SNP was identified through conditional and joint analysis within the context of lipid traits.
title: Genetically regulated gene expression underlies lipid traits in Hispanic cohorts

finding: The exonic polymorphism rs5498 in the ICAM1 gene was associated with an elevated level of triacylglycerols, increasing the risk of coronary artery disease, as suggested by previous clinical associations. This SNP's association highlights its role in cardiovascular disease susceptibility.
title: Genetically regulated gene expression underlies lipid traits in Hispanic cohorts

finding: The SNP rs3752246 was found in association with LOAD through less accessible chromatin regions surrounding the ABCA7 locus. The decreased accessibility correlated with differential expression of genes in the vicinity of this SNP, indicating a possible mechanism by which this locus may influence the risk of developing LOAD.
title: Sex dependent glial-specific changes in the chromatin accessibility landscape in late-onset Alzheimer’s disease brains

finding: The rs429358 SNP was associated with the <APOE4> allele, and its presence affected cerebrovascular response (CVR) into interactions with amyloid-beta (Aβ) deposition, specifically leading to impaired response inhibition in carriers. This finding related to cognitive dysfunction in aging.
title: Cerebrovascular response to exercise interacts with individual genotype and amyloid-beta deposition to influence response inhibition with aging

finding: The rs7412 SNP was associated with the <APOE3> allele which served as a protective factor in the study. It contributed to how individuals were classified in terms of <APOE> genotype and interactions with Aβ deposition and CVR, impacting cognitive response inhibition.
title: Cerebrovascular response to exercise interacts with individual genotype and amyloid-beta deposition to influence response inhibition with aging

finding: Associated with carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), rs145035679 exhibited a protective effect with a significant p-value of 1.07×10−8, while increasing the risk for carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA 19-9) with p-value 5.81×10−5. This SNP's association with Fucosyltransferase 6 (FUT6) indicated its relevance to pancreatic, breast, and colorectal cancers.
title: Phenome-wide association study of a comprehensive health check-up database in a Korea population: Clinical application & trans-ethnic comparison

finding: This splice donor variant showed significant association with coronary vessel calcium scoring (p-value 4.29×10−5) and was associated with Phospholipase D3 (PLD3), which has been linked to Alzheimer's disease in both East Asian and European populations.
title: Phenome-wide association study of a comprehensive health check-up database in a Korea population: Clinical application & trans-ethnic comparison

finding: The A49V variant was found to abolish recognition by Neisseria Opa74, indicating that it may impair the binding of certain bacterial adhesins to CEACAM1, potentially affecting colonization by Neisseria pathogens.
title: Evolution of host-microbe cell adherence by receptor domain shuffling

finding: The Q89H variant was shown to abrogate binding to both Opa52 and Opa74, demonstrating a significant alteration in how CEACAM1 interacts with specific bacterial adhesins, which could have implications for human susceptibility to infections such as gonorrhea.
title: Evolution of host-microbe cell adherence by receptor domain shuffling

finding: The presence of the APOE-ε4 allele, determined by genotyping rs7412, produced distinct changes in the composition of the plasma proteome, linking to pathways related to atherosclerosis, lipid transport, extracellular matrix, and synaptogenesis signaling. This finding was significant in the context of Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk.
title: APOE genotype or presence of brain amyloid alters the plasma proteome in cognitively normal, elderly subjects

finding: Similar to rs7412, the genotype at rs429358 related to the APOE-ε4 allele was associated with altered plasma proteome profiles. The expressed pathways included those previously linked to AD pathology, further confirming the relationship between APOE allele status and systemic proteomic changes in AD risk contexts.
title: APOE genotype or presence of brain amyloid alters the plasma proteome in cognitively normal, elderly subjects

finding: The SNP rs10420324 was associated with the regulation of the susceptibility to antisocial personality disorder through its effect on the AMPA receptor auxiliary subunit TARP γ-8. Given its relevance to a behavioral phenotype, the finding indicated a direct link between the genetic variant and the modulation of mental health disorders.
title: Genetic variations in G-Quadruplex forming sequences affect the transcription of human disease-related genes

finding: The SNP rs429358 was associated with Alzheimer's disease and recognized as a major missense mutation. It was also part of a synthetic association with another SNP located between APOE and APOC1, which exhibited near-perfect correlation with rs429358 and another SNP residing in a potential enhancer, emphasizing the complexities involved in the genetic architecture of Alzheimer's disease.
title: On the contribution of genetic heterogeneity to complex traits

finding: The SNP rs429358 was associated with higher protein oxidation in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), particularly related to the ferritin light chain (FTL) which was increased in individuals with the ApoE4 allele. This finding provided insights into the role of ApoE alleles in iron deposition and oxidative damage in the prefrontal cortex during AD.
title: Alzheimer’s Disease associations of ferritin and glutathione with oxidative damage and neuronal loss

finding: The SNP rs7412 was also linked to alterations in iron metabolism in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD), specifically influencing the levels of ferritin light chain (FTL) and associated with neuron loss. The presence of the ApoE4 allele corresponding to this SNP showed a relationship with impaired iron transport and decreased antioxidant defenses, further elucidating genetic factors that contribute to neurodegeneration in AD.
title: Alzheimer’s Disease associations of ferritin and glutathione with oxidative damage and neuronal loss

finding: The SNP 25505C>T (rs3211371) in CYP2B6, which is identified as R487C, was highlighted due to its significant functional effect on enzyme activity. The total frequency of this SNP was around 0.5, with an individual frequency of about 0.1.
title: Non-additivity of the functional properties of individual P450 species and its manifestation in the effects of alcohol consumption on the metabolism of ketamine and amitriptyline

finding: The SNP 18053A>G (rs2279343) in CYP2B6, referred to as K262R, was also noted for its functional importance. It had an approximate frequency of 0.15, significantly increasing the turnover rate and altering substrate specificity, making it consequential for the metabolism of ketamine and amitriptyline.
title: Non-additivity of the functional properties of individual P450 species and its manifestation in the effects of alcohol consumption on the metabolism of ketamine and amitriptyline

finding: The SNP 15631G>T (rs3745274) in CYP2B6, recognized as Q172H, was reviewed for its detrimental effect on enzyme activity. It had a frequency of around 0.3 and was among the most frequently occurring SNPs with functional implications.
title: Non-additivity of the functional properties of individual P450 species and its manifestation in the effects of alcohol consumption on the metabolism of ketamine and amitriptyline

finding: This SNP was identified as an intronic variant of the HPN gene and showed strong associations with triglycerides and total cholesterol, contributing to the analysis of lipid phenotypes.
title: A method to map and interpret pleiotropic loci using summary statistics of multiple traits

finding: The missense variant rs116843064 in the ANGPTL4 gene was significantly associated with incident coronary heart disease (CHD), highlighting its role in lipid metabolism and CHD risk.
title: Genetic loci associated with prevalent and incident myocardial infarction and coronary heart disease in the Cohorts for Heart and Aging Research in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE) Consortium

finding: In the analysis, the SNP rs56113850 was originally found to be significantly associated with the metabolite paraxanthine, displaying a p-value of 2.2 × 10−19. However, in the context of the analysis conducted with the DrFARM model, a significant association was also identified for the metabolite 1-methylurate at the same SNP, which was initially weak with a p-value of 0.0013 in the single metabolite GWAS. The DrFARM approach yielded a much stronger p-value of 3.9 × 10−13 for 1-methylurate, which is valid due to the known metabolic relationship between paraxanthine and 1-methylurate, as both are linked through the CYP2A6 enzyme.
title: DrFARM: Identification and inference for pleiotropic gene in GWAS

finding: This SNP was found in the same research study of critically ill patients and was located on 19p13.2, near the gene TYK2, contributing to its association with severe respiratory symptoms of COVID-19.
title: Human genetic variants associated with COVID-19 severity are enriched in immune and epithelium regulatory networks

finding: The intronic variant rs192943660 in CPAMD8 was also identified as having a strong association with retinal detachment.
title: Insight into the genetic aetiology of retinal detachment by combining small clinical and large population-based datasets

finding: The missense variant rs35033974 was associated with the identification of TEX101-associated proteins through proteomic measurement in human spermatozoa. This finding highlighted the significance of the SNP in relation to sperm quality and function in the context of male reproductive health.
title: Identification and quantification of human relaxin proteins by immunoaffinity-mass spectrometry

finding: The SNP rs10420324 was identified as regulating susceptibility to antisocial personality disorder through its influence on the AMPA receptor auxiliary subunit TARP gamma-8. This finding suggested a significant role of this specific genetic variation in the neurobiological pathways that may underpin behaviors associated with this mental health condition.
title: Understanding prefrontal cortex functions by decoding its molecular, cellular and circuit organization

finding: The variant rs8100011 in the ZNF45 gene was found to have a near-GWAS significance association with BMI (P=1.04 × 10−7) and acted as a cis-expression quantitative trait locus (cis-eQTL) influencing gene expression inversely correlated with BMI.
title: Multifaceted genome-wide study identifies novel regulatory loci for body mass index in Indians

finding: In the context of dyslipidemia and atherosclerosis, the intronic rs10401969 in SUGP1 was associated with candidate genes LPAR2, GMIP, GATAD2A, and TM6SF2. The minor C allele of this SNP was hypothesized to lead to a reduction in circulating lipids and an increased risk of atherosclerosis due to LPAR2 involvement, alongside a potential higher risk of fatty liver disease linked to TM6SF2.
title: Zebrafish larvae as a model system for systematic characterization of drugs and genes in dyslipidemia and atherosclerosis

finding: The minor T allele in rs3794991 was correlated with higher expression of GATAD2A in whole blood. Mutations in gatad2ab in zebrafish larvae suggested a role in glucose metabolism, as larvae with this mutation exhibited lower glucose levels, which was consistent with the association of the minor T allele with an increased risk of type-2 diabetes in humans.
title: Zebrafish larvae as a model system for systematic characterization of drugs and genes in dyslipidemia and atherosclerosis

finding: The SNP rs492602 in the FUT2 locus achieved a genome-wide significant p-value of 7.02 × 10-10, marking it as one of the previously reported signals of selection.
title: Scalable probabilistic PCA for large-scale genetic variation data

finding: The SNP rs12721051 was located in the 3' UTR region of the APOC1 gene, identified as a GWAS signal for total cholesterol levels. It was one of the top driven trans-eQTLs for gene ZC3H12B, suggesting a significant association with Alzheimer's dementia (AD) driven by trans-eQTL effects.
title: Bayesian Genome-wide TWAS method to leverage both cis- and trans- eQTL information through summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs4420638, located downstream of APOC1, was in linkage disequilibrium with the APOE-E4 allele (rs429358) and was identified as a GWAS signal for various blood lipid measurements and Alzheimer's dementia. It was also recognized as a trans-eQTL affecting gene ZC3H12B.
title: Bayesian Genome-wide TWAS method to leverage both cis- and trans- eQTL information through summary statistics

finding: SNP rs56131196 was located downstream of APOC1 and identified as a GWAS signal for Alzheimer's dementia. It was categorized as a trans-eQTL for gene ZC3H12B, further showing its role in the regulation of gene expression linked with AD pathology.
title: Bayesian Genome-wide TWAS method to leverage both cis- and trans- eQTL information through summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs157592 was found in the regulatory region of APOC1 and was identified as a GWAS signal associated with Alzheimer's dementia. It was part of the top driven trans-eQTLs for gene ZC3H12B, indicating its contribution to AD through trans-eQTL mechanisms.
title: Bayesian Genome-wide TWAS method to leverage both cis- and trans- eQTL information through summary statistics

finding: The SNP rs773902 was significantly associated with platelet function and variations in DNA methylation at the F2RL3 locus. It explained 48% of the variability in PAR4 reactivity but showed no direct correlation with PAR4 protein levels. Additionally, there was evidence suggesting that changes in platelet reactivity could be driven by methylation effects rather than direct functional effects on the protein.
title: Epigenetic regulation of PAR4-related platelet activation: mechanistic links between environmental exposure and cardiovascular disease

finding: This nonsense mutation in FUT2 was key in determining the secretor phenotype in Lewis blood group assessments and was found to have implications for phenotype classification accuracy.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: This SNP (Leu20Arg) was part of the Lewis blood group analysis and demonstrated comprehensive discordances with other variants in predicting the null phenotype, highlighting the complexity of these loci.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Analyzed in conjunction with other variants for inferring Lewis null phenotypes, showing the critical role of multiple alleles in accurate phenotype prediction.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Part of the analysis for determining the Lewis blood group, this variant along with others helped in achieving higher concordance when accounting for rare allelic differences.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: This variant was identified in Omani individuals and contributed to refined predictions of Lewis blood group phenotypes, particularly in null phenotype cases.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: This rare SNP was identified in a discordant individual whose phenotype indicated a weak secretor allele, emphasizing the nuanced genetic diversity within this population.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Associated with weak secretor status, this variant played a role in improving concordance predictions in blood group typing when combined with other analyses.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: Analyzed in relation to variations in secretor status among individuals, contributing to the understanding of complex blood group genetics.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: This SNP (Arg77His) was part of the Lutheran blood group analysis, where it demonstrated a high concordance rate in inferring antigen presence.
title: Characterization of Blood Group Variants in an Omani Population by Comparison of Whole Genome Sequencing and Serology

finding: The SNP rs112481437 was identified as being associated with the gene APOE, which is specifically expressed in astrocytes. SnapHiC analysis revealed that this SNP was located within an active enhancer approximately 150Kb downstream of the APOE transcription start site (TSS), suggesting its role in regulating APOE expression within astrocytes, particularly in the context of Alzheimer's disease (AD).
title: SnapHiC: a computational pipeline to map chromatin contacts from single cell Hi-C data

finding: Similar to rs112481437, the SNP rs138137383 was also linked to APOE expression through SnapHiC analysis. It was found within an active enhancer approximately 200Kb downstream of the APOE TSS. This connection indicated that rs138137383 could also influence the regulation of APOE in astrocytes and was relevant to the genetic predisposition to Alzheimer's disease (AD).
title: SnapHiC: a computational pipeline to map chromatin contacts from single cell Hi-C data

finding: Detected as a potential outlier for ER-negative breast cancer, highlighting a potential genetic relation.
title: Coffee consumption and risk of breast cancer: a Mendelian Randomization study

finding: This SNP was originally identified as a significant risk factor for Alzheimer's disease (AD). The context of the study highlighted its involvement in different alleles of the APOE gene, which plays a critical role in lipid metabolism and neuronal repair, implicating the ε4 allele as a strong genetic risk factor for AD.
title: Mitochondrial pathway polygenic risk scores are associated with Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: This SNP was also significantly associated with the APOE gene and its alleles, particularly the impact of the ε2 allele on AD risk. Like rs429358, this SNP contributes to the classification of individuals into ε2, ε3, and ε4 alleles, with ε2 being related to a protective effect against AD.
title: Mitochondrial pathway polygenic risk scores are associated with Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs769449 was found to have a strong association with high cholesterol, with a p-value of less than 1e-100. Initially, it showed no association with hypertension, but once conditioned on high cholesterol, a significant association emerged (p=1.43e-8), indicating a possible causal path where high cholesterol acts as a collider in the relationship with hypertension.
title: Constraint-based analysis for causal discovery in population-based biobanks

finding: The variant rs405509 was associated with brain differences observed between carriers and non-carriers in studies focused on Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk populations. The findings indicated that individuals carrying this allele exhibited alterations in brain connectivity that align with known AD-related pathologies, supporting its relevance in understanding early-stage disease impacts among aging populations.
title: Brain connectivity during Alzheimer’s disease progression and its cognitive impact in a transgenic rat model

finding: The common variant rs6511720 in the LDLR intron had a noted association with reduced LDL-C, providing suggestive evidence of its role in lipid metabolism as observed through further conditional analysis.
title: Whole genome sequence analysis of blood lipid levels in >66,000 individuals

finding: This SNP was associated with contact eQTLs, particularly in the TFPT locus, where it interacted with the promoter regions of the TFPT gene and another gene called OSCAR. It was in tight linkage disequilibrium with an eQTL for OSCAR that showed a significant positive correlation with TFPT expression.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: The SNP was tightly linked to rs10415777 and served as an eQTL for OSCAR, correlating positively with TFPT expression. It highlighted the interconnectivity of gene expression regulation involving multiple loci.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: Linked to EID2, this SNP was part of a trimodal QTL highlighted for its role in inflammation-related pathways and shared associations with GWAS traits.
title: Shared and distinct molecular effects of regulatory genetic variants provide insight into mechanisms of distal enhancer-promoter communication

finding: The SNP rs373201614 was associated with a position in the zinc finger domain of the ZNF528 protein that contacts DNA nucleotides. It represented a rare human polymorphism, where humans possess a Glutamine at this position compared to a Histidine in bonobos. This difference potentially impacted the repressor potency of ZNF528, suggesting that this SNP contributed to different TE interactions in humans compared to other primates, highlighting its role under positive selection in humans, including Denisovans and Neanderthals.
title: Regulatory networks of KRAB zinc finger genes and transposable elements changed during human brain evolution and disease

finding: This SNP showed evidence of a secondary signal in pancreatic fat studies (conditional p=5.71e-10) linking it to fat percentage.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: This SNP associated with pancreatic iron, despite no previous associated traits (p=5.9e-10, beta=0.06), suggesting a novel connection.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: This SNP was independently associated with VAT volume (p=2.9e-11, beta=-0.04), indicating its relevance in fat distribution.
title: Systematic quantification of health parameters from UK Biobank abdominal MRI using deep learning

finding: The AA genotype of rs769449 was found to be more associated with Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and Late Mild Cognitive Impairment (LMCI) compared to other groups, suggesting a potential risk factor for these conditions.
title: A generalization of partial least squares regression and correspondence analysis for categorical and mixed data: An application with the ADNI data

finding: The GG genotype of rs2075650 was associated with increased AV45 uptake and higher ADAS13 scores, marking it a contributor to the progression towards Alzheimer's Disease and Late Mild Cognitive Impairment.
title: A generalization of partial least squares regression and correspondence analysis for categorical and mixed data: An application with the ADNI data
